reviewText: Strike Suit Zero (SSZ) is a frustatingly beautiful game; the personification of a game with excellent gameplay marred by horrible enemy variation and an outlandish story. You are a pilot of a fleet taking off to exterminate an alien threat. The game's namesake ship however isn't even obtainable until the third mission - and even then you are charged with taking other ships such as the interceptor (a variation on the starting ship) and a bomber (which was actually pretty cool to operate). The aspect of the game that makes it most difficult is the combat: I want frentic warfare - not a jumbled mess. The dogfights are engaging if only for a moment; taking down capitol ships is an exercise in bullet/missle-sponges; and using the strike suit is like drunkingly blasting ships. Plus it leaves you more vulnerable to attacks - which makes no sense because you have to garner flux to use it and equipping (transforming) the suit should make you more of a bad ♥♥♥. Instead it makes you a sitting duck that relies on wobbly shooting (granted, lock-on firing is available). The story actually has a good conclusion but everything before it is wonky. At some random point there is a grand coupe de tat that is massively overlooked because you are too busy trying to master the controls to even pay attention to the dialogue.\n\nThe game's greatest weakness is that it doesn't flaunt the suit! Let me free fly with this piece of machinery. Make it more controllable. Make it worth garnering flux! Sadly, the game falls flat for me, and beating it was a months-long mission whose only vincidation of knocking off one more game off my protruberent Steam library.

reviewText: I took down my earlier review after giving up trying to reconfigure my logitech gamepad and settling with KB+M.  Since I play most of my games using the latter, I don't know why I initially tried to shoehorn the game controls to the former.  The only thing I rebinded were plasma shot/missle selection and single/double shot toggle to the scroll wheel and mouse button 3 respectively.  Then I lowered the sensitivity of strike suit mode to match that of the ship.  After that the gameplay opened up and I must say that it is now smooth like butter.  Nothing is more satisfying than whizzing around a capital ship in strike suit mode and stripping away all of its turrets leaving it as a defenseless husk ready to be taken down.  Anyways, the story is not anything worth writing home about, but it serves its purpose in moving the game along.  The backdrops are beautiful and the gameplay works for me after tweaking some of the lackluster default bindings.

reviewText:
So... it's a starfighter that transforms into a Gundam suit. Spaceship shaped like a person is still the dumbest idea ever (yes, even dumber than the double-decker couch). In addition to being a stupid idea (seriously; why does a spaceship need legs? They don't do anything), it's poorly executed.

The first three missions of SSZ are solid. Great game. It's freelancer with a bit of a facelift and no trading business to distract from the action. Then you actually get the Strike Suit and the game becomes unbearable. On top of the absolutely useless targeting system, the redundant (and pointless) HUD elements and lack of control customization, controlling this thing is just an absolute mess.

Yes, they finally patched-in the ability to re-map the controls but not all of them. Dodge is still hard-bound to double-tap a movement key." So when I have all my movement bound to proper control axes
date: dodge is physically impossible. I can't "double-tap" my flightstick to the left. Also: the Strike Suit can't roll.\n\nBottom line: consolized beyond playability. Not a PC game. Absolutely do not buy. Whatever you want this to be
recommended: you probably want it to have the basic requirements of playable one expects in a PC game
votesTotal: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Strike Suit Zero seems like a good game. It has pretty backdrops, some fun and exciting music, and the promise of a robotic mech spaceship to annihilate enemies. But the gameplay is so frustrating that playing it is a chore, and a frustrating one at that.

The basics combat system is good enough. It's fairly easy to get the hang of picking off enemies and sending missiles in every direction. In fact, Strike Suit Zero feels the best when it has you fighting against dozens of enemy fighters, honing in on enemies to build up to the moment where you can transform and unleash hell. But that's a small part of the game. At least 50% of the game is attacking larger stationary ships, taking out cargo, or blowing up turrets, all of which is so boring or frustrating that it brings down the little bit of fun the dogfights provide.

To make matters worse, there is a constant barrage of turrets, cannons, and other non-evadable damage that not only steadily drains health but keeps the screen in a disorienting panic that's less exhilirating than it is confusing. Many missions, especially the incredibly tedious ones that involve picking off every turret from a large cruiser, turned into me going for an attack, then flying aimlessly while my shield recharged before trying again. Rinse lather repeat.

If you're looking for your fill of space dogfighting, I don't think Strike Suit Zero is your best bet. There are many older games, and even some very recent ones that are starting to fill that hole better. If you're dedicated to playing every space game out there, you'll probably have fun with it, but otherwise I'd sit this one out.

reviewText: This game feels like a generic space shooter. It is like Freelancer except that you can't go wherever you want, and you can't take the missions you want. I was looking forward to using the strike suit, but that is also disappointing. In strike suit mode all you get is more damage to your normal guns, missile spamming abilities, auto-aim (if you want it), and the ability to dodge incoming attacks. Dodging in strike suit mode actually seems less effective against missiles than using the deflect ability in normal flight mode :(.  Strike suit mode also runs out very quickly when you try to use a lot of missiles, and then you are just back to normal flight mode. Most of the levels are just fighting waves of enemies and blowing up large carrier space ships, which gets old fast. The final level feels like it is trying to be more like Star Fox and it doesn’t work out. There are no enemies, and you just navigate through tight corridors. This game isn’t worth your money.

reviewText: Strike Suit Zero is a fairly pretty but poorly executed game. Little thought was put into what makes a game fun rather than frustrating. You will most likely spend half of the game trying to accommodate its awkward control layout and the other half regenerating your shields.\n\nThe controls aren't at all natural. It will take a few levels until you learn to adjust to the clumsiness of it all. Once you do you'll immediately be hit with a completely different control scheme as the Strike Suit" mechanic comes into play
date: turning your space ship into a powerful mech warrior. The transition between control schemes is jarring and hard to get used to
recommended: I'm not sure I'll ever really be comfortable with the switch.\n\nThere will be times when the enemy A.I. will play dirty and seemingly cheat. They are incredibly accurate and agile
hoursPlayed: with the ability to stay directly out of your line of sight no matter how fast you turn. They can manage to fire directly at you at a 90 degree angle from hundreds of metres away and hit every shot. They will also often fly in groups
helpfulPercent: in order to take you down. Meanwhile your team mates are miles away fighting their own one-on-one battles.\n\nWhen the time comes that a mission requires you to carry an extremely valuable payload with a disadvantaged vehicle
votesHelpful: you will often have to "lone wolf" the entire mission. On the other hand
votesTotal: when you're in a capable enough vehicle
votesFunny: you're often tasked with protecting similar ships in similar circumstances. For some reason when it's your turn there is no one around to help which is incredibly unfair as you're left to pick off the enemy one by one with a less than capable ship when it shouldn't have to be your job."

reviewText:
I'm confused by all the good reviews for this game. Sure, the graphics look nice, but the controls! Oh, the controls! I got fed up right after the initial training segment.

I tried using an Xbox 360 controller as well as keyboard and mouse and, even with customizations, I couldn't get comfortable. The problem is that the leftight movement doesn't behave like you'd expect. You would expect the you'd go left when pressing left and right when pressing right, but your ship goes into more of a barrel role which leaves you upside down and completely disoriented. I know this is in outer space so it won't control like, say, StarFox, but I have to believe there was a better way to do these controls than this.

If you are willing to suffer through this, or somehow manage to get comfortable with the controls, then I'm sure you could have fun. If you are looking for a good shooter that you can jump into and start having fun, look elsewhere.

reviewText:
A space dogfighting game with arcade levels of fun.  Unique to this one is the ability to use Strike Mode -- temporarily transforming your fighter into a powerful mech capable of free three-dimensional movement.  This game is fast-paced, but encourages a strategic approach to combat and completing mission objectives, switching between Strike Mode and the standard fighter as is appropriate for the task at hand, managing energy efficiently to maximize Strike Mode's effectiveness, and targeting weak points and weapons to cripple enemy ships while defending your own.
It's a great game, lots of fun, and surprisingly intellectually engaging as well.
Totes recommend.
10/10, would mech again.

reviewText:
Silly, atmospheric, shallow entertainment. This game has none of the depth and little of the character of the Freelancer games, while seeming in some respects a love-letter to them, despite its other inspirations. It is nonetheless a great deal of fun, with good music, good voice acting, decent if clichéd writing and enjoyably varied and balanced weapon systems and loadouts for your missions.

It has good short term replay value due to the bonus objectives and unlockables, and the difficulty is well-balanced, to my tastes, for someone with a bit of experience with space fighter videogames.

I highly recommend it at or below the price of £8-$15, as a loose sum across currencies, momentary exchange rates be damned.

reviewText:
Move along, you've played this game before.
If you've ever had a story about humans colonizing space, you know this plot.
If you've ever played any space shooter at all, you've played this game.
In fact you know what? Just go download Freespace 2. Download the launcher, it'll come with mods that will have the same graphics as this game. The plot will be a little more interesting and the controls will feel more like you are actually controlling a space ship.
I've only played through the first mission, but it's so boring I can't get to the second one.
If you've never played a space shooter and know very little sci-fi, this game is for you! There is nothing specifically wrong with it. It's just meh.

reviewText:
Ok I've been playing this for the better part of an hour and I have to say I kinda want my money back even though it was on sale . Dont get me wrong love the games that it gets it inspiration from HomeWorld(come on Homeworld 3), Freelancer, Gundum,.etc, but for me the conrols are very sensitive even when turned all the way down. I could never really get a clean shot on any of the enemies. It felt like i was just getting lucky and destroying stuff becuse the computer decided to fly in a straight line to give me a shot. The mouse should not have been used to steer the ship if you move the mouse too far it will fling you in a hard turn that is hard to come out of. Its almost like the made it so you would have to buy a game pad, but i dont want to have to go out and get one of those just to enjoy this game. A and D only roll the ship i would like to change it so that it turned the ship and the mouse just controled the orientation of the targeting recticle.

The game is very good looking from what I have been playing so far it reminds me of Zone of the Enders but just a tad bit slower. Visually it is spot on good explosions if you just happen to be a little to close the the ship that is being destroyed than they are a little too bright. Some of the background elements are great some of them i want to have as a background on my desktop.

For now i am going to uninstall it I may get a flight stick to play it properly becsuse it is a little wierd with a mouse and keyboard. So I recommend it if you have a flight stick if you dont and still want to give it a go then i recommend putting the mouse sensativity on low settings that way you will be able to keep up with your enemies in the game and you wont zip past them. And with a flight stick im expecting this to be like Ace Combat.

reviewText: really cool space war game. The mecha action is there but very limited bursts like around 10 seconds until you are out of flux and then you have to be in ship mode for the other 95% of the game. I guess they do that because in mech mode you are extremely powerful and can easily wipe out half the guns on a cruiser or take out corvettes with ease while side stepping gunfire. But don't let the beautiful space scenery fool you though, you will hardly have any time to enjoy it and only during the beginning of the mission. Within seconds you'll be under heavy fire from fighters and warships and you do your best to stay alive while trying to attack. But if you do want beautiful scenery while cruising space then SSZ isn't for you. There is no cruise control! only full on attack!

reviewText: I've only got a few hours on record, and only made it to the fourth mission. Considering I got this on sale for $5 I'm as happy as could be! This is the first space combat sim I've found that feels really authentic, where aggressive posturing, liberal use of secondaries, and strong piloting skills make a real difference. Getting your first mech is friggin awesome, though it is difficult to control.\n\nControls for the game have me a little worried. I'm using a Kinobo Playstation USB controller that I've mapped for the game specifically. It kinda feels necessary to make it work given the high number of controls you really want to have access to at your fingertips, especially given that the difference between your fighter controls and mech controls is very noticable and you need to be able to move between either without blinking. Mouse and keyboard might be able to make it work, but it feels like a bit of a gamble. Investing in a controler is definitely worthwhile.

reviewText:
Game's hard and will catch the unprepared and beat them hard. Now that rhymes.

A rare of its kind - a space battle theme and you control a gundam-esque robot.

Across a series of 13 linear missions or so, you'll be required to complete objectives, from defending a spaceship to eliminating enemies. Being linear, that's it, replayability is minimal unless you want to try harder difficulty. Some missions can be somewhat aggravating especially if you are required to protect a frigate, for example. Not only can't you fly freely far away from the objective, you also need make sure to eliminate incoming threats (and often in full force) while fending off the attacks towards your own suit. Thankfully you have the transformation ability that's incredibly useful to maneuver thru the battlefield and get a better shooting stance faster.

That said, metacritic should've been 80. That comes from people whining about difficulty level - a sign of a good game.

And being indie, graphic is impressively well made. Just try to check the trailers/screenshots around to see.

Until the replacement comes, this is the best space-sim action game on Steam. Grab it when it's on sale.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you like mecha anime like Macross Frontier, play this game.

In it's normal mode, the fighter combat is pretty solid although most weapons feel like pea-shooters.
However despite what some say, I feel that the game's a bit too easy on the normal difficulties. In fact, most of the time I end up dying due to rubbing my hull against an enemy ship than from enemy fire. Another complaint is that the controls for the space-mecha mode are broken to the point in which you can basically give up on manually aiming. I end up selecting my target beforehand and hit-and-running my target into submission.

Despite it's flaws, it's a really solid game. I throughly enjoyed it and I would recommend you buy it.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Strike Suit Zero has strength in its guns, but none in its voice.

The story is about as compelling as piece of cold chicken. There's no effort in building any kind of drive outside of 'there's the bad guys and their ships are red, kill 'em.'

Guns shoot and kills as they should, that's their job after all. The idea of a gundam starfighter just blows me away, this is the most fun I've had in an aircraft game.

The later levels are obnoxiously long, and there are no save game slots for during missions. Either you beat the level and wait ten minutes for the next one to start, or you die and wait five minutes for the level to restart.

This game is broken in comparision to Strike Suit Infinity, Zero being not worth the effort to beat.

5 out of 10 stars

reviewText: Taking part in dogfights in space is both exilhirating and unforgiving. The transformable Strike Suit itself makes mince-meat of grunt-level enemies, but taking down larger ships can be rather tedious. Most of the levels are highly replayable for ♥♥♥♥♥ing better scores to unlock various upgrades, but you're in risk of a nervous breakdown when applying that to the final levels. The DLC also adds longevity to the experience with some extra levels and a new transforming model, the Raptor, which is LUDICROUSLY fast compared to the Strike Suit. If you have nerves of steel, it's worth checking this game out.

reviewText: SSZ is a mixed bag - great graphics, an absolutely stunning soundtrack by Paul Ruskay but unfortunately the gameplay is a bit uneven sometimes. reviewText: really cool space war game. The mecha action is there but very limited bursts like around 10 seconds until you are out of flux and then you have to be in ship mode for the other 95% of the game. I guess they do that because in mech mode you are extremely powerful and can easily wipe out half the guns on a cruiser or take out corvettes with ease while side stepping gunfire. But don't let the beautiful space scenery fool you though, you will hardly have any time to enjoy it and only during the beginning of the mission. Within seconds you'll be under heavy fire from fighters and warships and you do your best to stay alive while trying to attack. But if you do want beautiful scenery while cruising space then SSZ isn't for you. There is no cruise control! only full on attack!

reviewText: I've only got a few hours on record, and only made it to the fourth mission. Considering I got this on sale for $5 I'm as happy as could be! This is the first space combat sim I've found that feels really authentic, where aggressive posturing, liberal use of secondaries, and strong piloting skills make a real difference. Getting your first mech is friggin awesome, though it is difficult to control.\n\nControls for the game have me a little worried. I'm using a Kinobo Playstation USB controller that I've mapped for the game specifically. It kinda feels necessary to make it work given the high number of controls you really want to have access to at your fingertips, especially given that the difference between your fighter controls and mech controls is very noticable and you need to be able to move between either without blinking. Mouse and keyboard might be able to make it work, but it feels like a bit of a gamble. Investing in a controler is definitely worthwhile.

reviewText: Strike Suit Zero offers fast-paced space action combat similar to Freespace, Freelancer, etc., but with beautifully designed graphics, and a more frantic pace. It's twitch-based combat make speed, control, and timing the most important things. It's singleplayer with a story, and has no RPG elements similar to Freelancer, but it challenges you to act quickly and set up attacks in a way that resembles typical fighting games.

reviewText:
the game gets repetitive pretty fast. jump in, destroy fighters, destroy torpedos, destroy turret/supply, end mission.
I read the other reviews saying just the same about the repetitve mission design, but I never thought it could be that boring.
the games jumps from battle to battle with absolutely no time in between.
the story is dull and not even worth following.
the voice acting is bad. for example: a captain of a capital ship reports with a stoic, bored voice that the hull has been breached and the life support is failing, then the ship explodes.
the skybox and the visual effects are nice, the ships have low resolution textures and look pretty uninspired.
the tranformation into the mech feels completely unneccesary.
IMO worth about 5 bucks.

reviewText: Everything about this game just misses the mark for me.. Graphics, gameplay and the controls in particular. The space combat can be fun however it can get a little tedious and frustrating (for me in particular, being an angry gamer) at times.. All these problems all just combine for an average space combat sim in my opinion. Also the game itself honestly is not good enough to be compared to other games of its genre specifically in ways of visual appeal/graphics, after all isn't space meant to be a beautiful enigma"?.. e.g Star Conflict is free to play (although some things must be payed for) however the controls and visuals are far superior than SSZ and for me (Star Conflict) "destroys" SSZ in the field of which SSZ professes to be the best at: Combat.. Strike Suit Zero has a good story and can be entertaining at points however those are the only positives I can state about this game.. If you are to get this game.. get it on sale..\n\nP.S: This is my opinion don't rage at me if I don't have the same viewpoint as you."

reviewText:
I love flying shooters, from arcade style sideways shooters to planes and everything in between. From all the space shooters I have played this one is the worst. The game looks pretty, has great music, and seems to have a decent story, but the controls and everything in between are terrible. With a controller the flying is on the right thumbstick, Not sure who thought that was a great idea but let that set the stage for the rest of the crap playability. The dialog is so low its practically muted, meaning you need to crawl through setting until you adjust the audio to where you can hear it.  This game is a classic case of how developers build a world but are clueless about making it enjoyable for players, from the audio, to controls, to the junk ship you ship, this game is a waste of space.

Gameplay fatal flaws:
Also being a 3D shooter, there is no distance to target over the lockon icon for the enemy you are tracking, and their so small but the icon stays the same size its impossible to tell when their right on top of you.  There is a distance thing with a picture in the lower left but I cant look at that while chasing these  mosquito enemies.

The enemies suffer from the syndrome of them flying all over like their hopped on drugs with no pattern or logic to what their doing.  Its like those sniper games where for no reason enemies run back and forth in place while sniping you from across the map with their guns while you with a sniper rifle are helpess.

Your ship is soooOOooo slow until you beat the mission and unlock the other ships.  HEY DEVS! how about just making it fun to begin with?  Picture a Volkswagen bug chasing a Ferrari and you get this game. This is a game where there are other ships but you cant access them until you beat a map, which means playing the crap way then later hey you can have fun, no thanks, your game sucks.

The nail in the coffin for me was the shooting mechanics, to fire a missle its right bumper meaning you must stop firing your machine guns to fire a missle.  What modern plane would be designed so terribly that only one weapon works at a time, this is the future right, I mean their in space.

reviewText: I'm not sure what to say, the game is great until about the third level, where you get switched into a different ship (the strike suit) and pretty much everything you've learned up to that point becomes invalid, and you suddenly have to learn a completely new control system while the enemies only get tougher. What's worse, it seems utterly impotent compared to the previous ship, but perhaps that is only because there is no explanation on how to properly use it?? Its weapons can't even shoot down torpedoes (which typically just go splat), how are you supposed to fight entire enemy fleets?\n\nThe artwork is beautiful, even if the special effects are a bit half-baked (cutscene hyperspacing?). I wish You could iron-out that spot where the gameplay just stalls and release it as an update, because up to that point it is a very fun game.

You know those escort missions in every game that almost universally suck? Imagine a game that's *just those missions*. Now imagine you're playing that game, except the bad guys are space ships and the things you're escorting are huge, slow, moving targets that are completely vulnerable at all times. Though to the game's credit, the space backdrop to all your allies' slow inevitable death is beautiful even when it's frustrating.\n\nThe story is also complete ♥♥♥♥, but that shouldn't come as a surprise to anyone.

With a clever soundtrack and new take on space ship fighter combat, Strike Suit Zero is well worth the $15.00 pricetag on it's head.  There is an immensely gratifying feeling when you activate the Strike Suit's transformation mode, watching your ship spin into a giant mecha to level entire fleets.

Some of the elements of the game in combat can feel a bit frustrating (trying to lock onto a target while your ship sways and overcompensates comes to mind), as well as loading times that have no excuse.

Overall, I call this game a buy.

Interesting concept and very nice graphics. There is a level of strategy as well, for instance, when in capital ship battles, taking out various hardpoints on larger ships to give your fleet an advantage and so forth. My only complaint is the clumsy controls, especially for keyboard & mouse. Somewhat difficult for accurate fire that is often necessary in dogfights, and Strike Suit controls take some getting used to, since you're constantly switching between fighter and SS modes. Overall the game is enjoyable, a pleasant remenisce of the Macross series.

So far so good.\n\nThe combat is fun though the slow unlocking of upgrades is annyoing made more so by the cumbersome and unintuitive targeting system and objective display.

The breathtaking space vistas aside, this is the closest I have ever felt to piloting a Gundam - taking down capital ships single-handedly and mowing down fighters. This is pretty amazing with a controller. And the music is very, very good. Seriously, even if you don't get the game, consider getting the soundtrack on iTunes or something (I got the OST as a DLC from the Steam store).

On the other hand, the difficulty curve is kind of ridiculous, even on the easiest difficulty. If you're a gamepad wizard (or an old-style masochist), I heartily recommend this game. You will have a blast. But if you, like me, just want to have casual fun blowing ♥♥♥♥ up with a Gundam, you'll be wowed by the visuals, music (awesome stuff) and general atmosphere for the first few missions then become increasingly frustrated as you hit a brick wall of insurmountable difficulty.

Caveat emptor.

reviewText: Genuinely surprised at the mediocre-negative reception this game is getting from sites like Eurogamer. The story and presentation leave a little to be desired (as to be expected from an indie title) but the gameplay itself is rock solid. It's difficult but not unfair, just as space flight sims should be. The addition of a Macross-esque transforming space ship mechanic is so well done it's a wonder how these types of games ever did without it.
Nicegame\n
If you like huge space-battles and being a dominator in Space, you should get this one.

The strike suit games, just so everyone knows, aren't space simulators, nor are they a Gundam-style clone. They're an arcade style space combat game, most like the Rogue Squadron games. If you liked the Rogue Squadron series (I know I did), you'll probably feel right at home with Strike Suit Zero. Just don't try to play with a flight stick, it doesn't really work as good as I would have liked. PROTIP: Xbox 360 controller is the way to play this game.
Ballkickingly hard at times but still enjoyable. The music by Homeworld composer Paul Ruskay is pretty rad.

Space Flight Sim. Check. Giant Transforming Mecha. Check. Great gameplay and graphics. Check. Sure, may be a bit repetitive, but if you are a fan of Robotech or Macross as much as you are a fan of Descent Freespace or Wing Commander, you will love this.
This game is what would happen if Tron and Star Wars had a baby.

If you have played Black Prophecy, this game captures the same feel of gameplay, being an action space fighter game, and does so in an excellent way. I would love to play more of this, and I would love to find another (not defunct) mmo that has the same kind of gameplay Black Prophecy did. Till then, this will have to do.

Strike Suit Zero is a intense and frantic game with a lot of significant flaws. Controls can feel complex and cumbersome, often akin to patting your head and rubbing your belly as you constantly shift between various weapons systems to chew through energy shields or armor more efficiently, time your EMP to throw off enemy missiles, manage weapon and thruster energy so as not to be left vulnerable while also keeping tabs on numerous objectives, enemy types, and friendlies that need more protection than Slippy ever did. Flipping into 'Strike' mode (AKA Mech mode) is only a temporary respite, cutting your maneuverability and boasting a whole different set of controls that must be mastered to maximize it's enormous firepower. It's overwhelming at times all of the stuff that needs to be kept track of, and the cluttered, boring missions don't help. However, when the game is firing on all cylinders and you get into a stride, there's absolutely nothing like SSZ in the genre that makes you feel like an ace pilot. The climax of one mission, for example, sees you screaming into combat as an outgunned allied battleship is melted, corkscrewing through a swarm of enemy fighters blasting at everything to build up flux in time. From there, you flip smoothly into Strike mode, strafing along the broadside of a massive enemy cruiser mashing turrets and hoping to god your shields can hold on for just a few milliseconds longer before shifting back to fighter mode and wheeling out for another run, eyes constantly watching the armor melting off your allied ship. Moments like these will be among the most memorable moments you can have with this game. Unfortunately, they'll also be peppered with hatred for the accursed bomber missions, long missions of kill this group of enemies

An old school space sim with new mechanics.
Strike Suit Zero is one of the early titles developped for the Oculus Rift but if you aren't that lucky yet, don't worry this game is still great.
The universe is very immersive, with it's great open spaces and impressive color palette, the game is visually striking. But it does not end there, there is full support for any type of control method (Mouse+Keyboard, Gamepad, Joystick+Keyboard, HOTAS) and the button mapping is really intuitive (just be sure to select Joystick+Keyboard when playing with a HOTAS). However, when it comes to controlling ships, there's not much to choose from. Being a recruit you'll start with a standard fighter then shortly after you'll unlock the Strike Suit and further down some other 2 ships bringing it to a total of four ships to choose from, which is not much. But the game being named Strike Suit Zero, you already guessed what the main ship will be. It's main feature is that is can transform into a Transformer like mech and fire lock on missiles and heavy caliber both using Flux as energy, this Flux can be regenerated over time and be destroying enemy targets. So yeah, it's pretty badass. But the game does not let you be badass for long as the didfficulty of missions ramp up very quickly and the ally AI is utterly useless, forcing you to always be at your best to triumph. The old school difficulty also applies to the ranking system, if you do as you are told you might get a medal, but if you do everyones job you'll earn silver or gold. Keep in mind that there is Platinum above and since you've already won the battle to yourself there is not much left to do!

Anyway, besides its frustrating difficulty Strike Suit Zero is a fantastic experience and a worthy one if you want to prepare for StarCitizen later this year (press time). With it's challenging but rewarding gameplay, this is a game that I recommend.

Do you like escort missions? No? Well tough. The game starts out quite well, with tight responsive controls and frankly great looking graphics, but the repetetive mission structure tends to get in the way of my enjoyment. Every mission I have played so far has at least one escort section and due to this the variety feels somewhat limited.

This game falls into the ''criminally underrated'' category. Remember when IGN gave Godhand a 3 when everyone else gave it a 7 or 8? It's kinda like that. I'm not gonna spend too much time on this, but the reviewers that gave it a low score did so because they are inept at playing anything harder than Mario. ''It's too hard'' was the MAIN complaint, and it's pathetic because it's not.

Anyway, think Star Fox 64's 'all-range mode', but with a lot more enemies. You get 13 missions with an unfolding plot, and upgrades along the way that are unlocked by completing optional objectives that present some difficulty, but hardly the difficulty the ♥♥♥♥♥-♥♥♥ reviewers say it posseses. You're given objectives in the middle of the mission, but it boils down to killing ♥♥♥♥ and blowing up big ships. Each mission varies up the scenario to avoid repetetiveness: protecting a fleet, taking out a ship in particular (or protecting it), taking out incoming torpedos, loss of missile systems.

Just a tip: press the camera button (default is 'C') to go into first person. You have to do this for both your fighter and the Strike Suit, otherwise you're in first person in fighter mode and third person in Strike mode. It makes the fighting a lot more intense and increases that sense of inertia.

Incredibly fun; highly recommended; intense dogfighting on dogfighting action; buy it now.

Fan of Space combat simulators?  Fan of the old 'X-wing' or 'Rogue Squadron' game series?  Love the classic anime titles such as Robotech and/or Super Dimension Fortress Macross?  This game will meet all those needs and more.  I'm not quite done with the game yet personally, but so far I'm loving every second of it.\n\nThe controls might need a little work, and the compatibility with existing controllers could be a little nicer and automatic instead of painfully testing each button.  But if you only play with Keyboard, then none of that will be a problem for you.

This game is really great. It has all the features of space combat simulation, and adds an extra gameplay improvement with the Strike Suit's strike mode.

Pursuit mode is dynamic both when you're against fighters and capital ships (the big ships). The targeting system is very efficient and allows you to easily spot the best target. Strike mode adds a new gameplay with a different (and more interesting) movement control (especially efficient against capital ships) and deadly weapons very useful against fighters.

The thirteen missions have a wide variety of objectives which make every one feel unique, and the improvement of both your ship and your pilot's abilities give it a high level of replayability.

Even better with a joystick, in first person view.

The game didn't leave a good impression on me early in, but I stuck through it until mission 12 hoping for it to grab me, and now I'm done with it.  The game just isn't well designed, and mission 12 fully expressed that to me.  The weapons you get are limited in selection throughout the level.  The objectives and things you do rarely change and deviate from a formula they repeat every other level or 2.  It's basically defend X, attack X, or attack turrets on X to then get to attack X afterwards.

Worse yet is on larger vehicles you're supposed to destroy you get little in terms of visual or auditory feedback that you're actually doing decent damage yourself, or if it's just your friendly ally ships.  When the objectives change, the game will do a poor job explaining what you actualy need to do, and point out targets that don't remotely matter to actually finishing it.

The game just does nothing remarkeable outside your strike suite can lock on, and let you paint multiple targets to fire a large missile barrage.  Fun for the first few times, but quickly becomes a tedious activity, as you'll use it a bunch to ween down health on ships with inflated HP.
Fun and addictive. Think Zone of The Enders meets Homeworld. Only 13 missions with rewards for repeating for better scores, bargain for < £4 on sale though.

I absolutely love this game. Came into it relatively blindly. Had just done a revisit of some of my older favorites from the Wing Commander series, and was looking to jump into something similar that made use of newer technology, and SSZ happened to be on sale on Steam that day, so I made the purchase without really knowing what I was getting into. Infinitely happy that I did. The controls take a little getting used to, but the game eases you into them by giving you what's essentially a tutorial mission, followed by a few missions that are pretty light on difficulty and present you with basic forms of each fighting scenario, for example squadrons of fighters you have to take down, a capital ship you have to protect, etc. Once you get used to the key placements it's all pretty straightforward in that regard. The graphics are nothing short of spectacular both in their smoothness running and in presentation. I'm playing on a fairly decent, but not cutting edge machine, and I've experienced very few framerate issues, really only dropping slightly when so much is happening on screen that it's more than my brain can process all at once either. The sound and music are just as good, really fitting the atmosphere of the game, helping to enhance the feeling that you're taking part in massive epic space battles. There's also a good amount of replay value added in the form of mission medals and stat upgrade unlocks, that I know have me revisiting mission after mission to try for higher scores and get the unlocks/medals that I want. The only thing even remotely negative that I can say about the game is that it's pretty light on plot. The majority of the plot is communicated through text that you get both in mission briefings and post-mission reports, along with some cutscenes that take place during missions, but at times it's developed so little that I found myself scratching my head when something big happened, feeling like I didn't really know what was going on at all. But at the same time it's really not the emphasis of the game. The fast-paced large scale beautifully rendered space battles in amazingly atmospheric settings is. So basically if you're looking for something really plot heavy, this may not be the game for you, but if you're looking for a straight up space battle simulator and can live without having much of a plot to go along with it then you won't regret the purchase.
Do not buy this crap game. Flying a lightweight interceptor feels like you're in a tug boat as it turns extremely slowly left-right and up-down. Enemies fly past your viewport constantly.

I really want to recommend this game, because it can be tremendously fun.  Unfortunately, it is also horrendously buggy, which makes it exceedingly frustrating: it's not enough to be good, you also have to be lucky, because luck is the only way to avoid the worst effects of the bugs.  If the devs ever get the bugs under control, then I'll happily change my review to recommend this game.

+ Gameplay is fun (most of the time).

- Playing with controller is difficult. I have an XBox360 controller for windows. The left stick is for rolling the ship (pretty useless), the right stick is for gearing. While certainly not the best game I've ever played, Strike Suit Zero nevertheless scratches a space combat shooter itch that I've had since playing Tachyon: The Fringe back in the early 2000s.  Indeed, SSZ seems to borrow many elements from Tachyon, including most of the mechanics, feel, and weapons.  The graphics in the game are a bit underwhelming, looking more like a game from the late 00s, rather than the 2010s.  Still, for an independent title that was funded through Kickstarter, SSZ is definitely worth your time.  The main draw of the game--the mech transformation--is actually the least fun, in my opinion.  I greatly prefer the starfighter mode to the mech mode.  But, if you are looking for a no-frills space shooter that calls to mind the golden age of the genre, then this game is certainly worth that money, especially if you can get it on sale.

This has been one of the most frustrating games I think I've ever owned.  Looks beautiful when in the game, but to get there, I had to set my main monitor to the Oculus Rift resolution of 1280x800 to play with the Rift.  Otherwise you end up with a small window in the upper right corner that does no good for Rift viewing.  Once in the game the menus are readable, but only if you keep your head very, very still.  Then when you think you have everything figured out, you try to tweak the little options in your menus, but ....can't figure out what controls to use in menus, can't use joystick apparently, so you're stuck taking off  the rift to try and see the keyboard, but standard keys do not work.  Had to escape out by doing a ctrl, alt, del because nothing else would let me.  I ran just the game without steam, but cannot use your Rift if you do that.  So I just went in to change all my controls to something I know, and now I'm going to try all of this again.  The main problem is probably my choice of controller, which is a Saitek X52, and when a menu pops up that says hit button 30 to continue" I have no idea which one they are talking about.  I tried them all but nothing got me past the menu

This game is great. For starters, the controls are fairly straightforward. Using a mouse and keypad works, but for the true experience you will definitely want to use a joystick. Controls with the gamepad don't seem too refined and could definitely use some work. Overall, the gameplay is intense, forcing you to choose your targets and weapons wisely. The battles are further enhanced by the beautiful galactic backdrops. Worth every penny.
Imagine if Homeworld, Freelancer and Macross had a threesome. This game would be the baby.

A game from a tiny developer with a successful kickstarter project, Strike Suit Zero is an accomplishment I'm sure many will remember. What this game lacks in complexity, it more than makes up for elsewhere. If anything, all you can really complain about is that it feels as though there's just not enough of it!

So you want to know what this game is, what it does, etc. Well, imagine for one moment if the RTS game Homeworld, was smooshed together with the TV series Battlestar Galactica, the pacing of Super R-Type, the mecha styling of Mobile Suit Gundam, the atmosphere and vibrance of Zone of the Enders and infused with the soul of the X3 series. Now imagine that all of that comes together in an orgy of frenetic 3d-space combat, beautiful, vibrant graphics, a challenging AI, a good selection of ships/mecha and weapons and a soundtrack reminiscent of the musical stylings of Talvin Singh.

Bottom Line : If you love your twitch gaming, but also want an atmospheric, challenging, not to mention stunning, 3d space shooter with an engaging story and an AI that'll keep you on your toes, then look no further. This really is a gem, and at under a fiver on steam, you've really got no excuses if this kind of thing is your cup of tea!

The default control layout for 360 pads could really use some work, but after messing with a bit, and giving the game a chance I'm really getting into Strike Suit Zero.  Efforts in the pure action space fighter genre have been weak to middling since Freespace 2 - I can now say that SSZ is comfortably cut above them.  It hasn't best Freespace 2's nigh unbeatable high water mark, but it is eminently entertaining and a good game in it's own right.  For a genre on hiatus (not dead!) this a laudable big step in reviving it.

reviewText: The controls made me sad. Rest of the game was ok though.

Luckily I bought this game after they fixed all the major issues, so no complaint there. Game works fine for me.
I've played this game the whole way through, and I can safely say I had an absolute blast. The combat was fun and fast paced, the ship designs were neat, though definitely more variety was a must there, yet overall the game had a very stylized look and feel to it. Plus the music was pretty damn bad ♥♥♥ as well. The fighting in the game seems so visceral, I love it in games where your the queen in a very large chess game. Also, the strike suit itself is pretty damn cool, shooting out tons of missles a la macross.
Although I must admit, the controls are pretty wonky. Not being able to flip around or do a quick 360 or anything like that is pretty annoying, not to mention the overall awkward control scheme you need to get used to. Voice acting and story is also pretty mediocre, could've used definite improvements there. Also, the missions get pretty repetitive, and the ones where you have to blow up specific buildings or such, with no fast way to turn around it really gets annoying fast.
Overall though, if you like fast action space combat games, this is one you should definitely get.
Fun so far
good game  vary hard it will take some time to get used to the game but other than that grate game :D
One of the best games I've played in a long time! Well worth the purchase.
can't recommend enough, fantastic game :)

An awesome space combat game. Think of it like Macross the video game. Combat is challenging, but fun and very flashy. Game starts off a bit slow, but picks up after mission 3 once you get the Strike Suit. The game can spike in difficulty very randomly, but never to the point of impossibility. The only thing I would hold against it is the bonus upgrades. Some of them ask you to complete a secondary objective of some sort. However, many of these objectives go against actually doing well on the mission. Very often, when I replayed the mission to get the secondary objective, I ended up doing far worse rating wise then I did just playing the mission normally.\n\nAll in all, a fantastic dog-fighting, large-scale, space combat game and well worth the price of $20. Even better when it's on sale.
So much more could be done with this game, I find Strike Suit Zero very fun.

Really enjoying ths game. It has a lot of what I like. Great Action, excellent graphics, simple to control and a storyline that is both complex but unobtrusive. If you have an inkling towards Space games I highly rcommend Strike Suit Zero.
Think Freelancer without the economy + mecha :D\nSimple, but lots of fun.

Mac users beware. I purchased the game a few months ago and as of the writing of this still have not been able to play it. I experience a black screen with only the audio playing. After following all available troubleshooting guides I contacted the developers through several methods (twitter, e-mail, forums, etc.) and while I recieved an e-mail response I never got any replies after submitting my computer data to them. With that being said, if you intend on playing this on a Mac computer just be aware that some users are experiencing issues and that the developers seem to be ignoring myself and others who are experiencing this issue. Until this critical issue is fixed and the developers actually provide support I cannot recommend it.
The game is awesome, but the controls are unmappable to anything that remotely makes sense to my brain.  I want left stick inverted, right stick non inverted.  Why can't I do that?

Probably one of the most fun Space battle dog-fight games i have played in a while.
Immediately drags you into the whole plot. Truly immersive and amazing story-telling to it. The graphics are just astounding and breath-taking. The gorgeous environment just leaves you wanting more.
The Dog-fights between fighters is fast-paced and extremly fun. Then there are massive-scale fights going on between frigates, cruisers and capital ships. Yay for fireworks!

8/10

Better than Strike Suit Infinity. If you're having trouble deciding which to purchase between to the two, look no further. Click the Buy button already; However, if you're not a fan of Space Combat/Mech Combat, then I wouldn't suggest this game what-so-ever. It plays like any traditional Space Combat game in the 90's and early millenia.

reviewerDisplayName: The Roamer of The Bright Sea
reviewText: This game, is awesome. Graphics 10/10. Gameplay 9/10 Story 8/10 Music 10/10. This game was beautifully created. Cheers to the creators. At first I thought that it looked Meh but once I bought it during the steam christmas sales, my thoughts did a full 180. I would have actually payed the whole price had I know how awesomely awesome this is. If you love space battles and hard battles, this game is for you. None of that casual bull that other space sims give you. This game thrusts you into the fray instantly and with out a single damn to give you. Perfect game, 9.9/10, would do again.
A little too challenging to play with the keyboard. Definitely better with a controller

I'm really enjoying this game. To put it simple, It's exacly as GUNDAM SEED, just made into a game. You will notice that the captaplut is the same design :P

The missions are a bit light on text content but all is voiced. Although I believe by mission 5 you will be skipping most of them. The plot is also weak, which makes me think they did not put much time into the writing, which for this game, i'm completly fine with.

As for the combat, it certainly needs polished. The fight can be caotic and if you are not familiar with your mouse sensativity you will find free aim completly unplayable. The lock on ability also needs more polished when in Striker mode, mostly tied to the free aim feature. Be aware that using the guns(rifle or energy) i did not find any trouble with it.
As for striker mode and persuit mode, it feels swift, DIFFERENT(really important) and balance. On Striker Mode(humanoid, GUNDAM FUN) you feel overpowered like you should, you can simple auto target everyone with Shift and gun them, dodge enemy fire, etc. But the limit you have with it, making that fun end a little bit early ends up balancing it and making hardcore a really challenging difficulty (Although i would like more of that mode). Notice that the multiple lock on feature is very bad, u need free aim and won't detect enemies that are there. It fail completly compared to something like Zone of the Ender, so much that you wouldn't use it at all almost. As for persuit mode, It feels different, both on the weapons you use(you have more range of weapons in this mode) and the fact that you can thrust away from situations that might turn way too bad.  Here i didn't had much to complain, it feels like a fighter should feel. The space bar is perfect to change mode btw.

Combat is caotic and the camera doesn't help. Then again, i like that part because it feels real, and having both 3rd person and cokpit views is a plus. The targetting system needs a bit polish, but i find the weapon selection limited. All weapons so far feel different and choice does matter, both guns and missles. But Only 2 buttons to cycle through either guns or missiles isn't enough. I would like to bind my weapons to 1-5 or similar and change them that way.

As for the UI, I don't actually like it, but it does the job. I would change many things, but those that I feel that pass personal preference and became somewhat damaging to the player are the fact that your weapons are display through text. Each should have a little image, a machine gun and a rail gun, a Rocket and a Seeker missile, for exemple, that would allow quick recognition of the weapon selected. This doesn't affect guns too much(your aim changes acordingly) but the missile selection is harder than it needs to be.

Lastly, regarding the aim i would like to see priority targets more distiguish. The game targetting is somewhat good, but it 3D icons suffer from the same problem games like BF4 and others. Its hard to target exacly what u want quickly or while dealing with an interceptor or changing targets.

To Conclude, I found this game alot of fun. The gameplay is fast, challenging and each feature feels different. Although there are not that many types of targets(don't expect 5 types of inteceptors, 10 types of carriers, like in ZotE), the missions are sufficiently different and the form you tackle a interceptor squad, or a carrier or a full on base with carriers and squads, while protecting your bombers, feel very well made. The game certainly needs polished, therefore I would like to see where it goes. Please keep them coming, i want to see more.

Think Transformers, but in space. The combat is fluid and enjoyable with a good balance between action and some downtime for the story. This game has Workshop support too, so if you like to Mod your games, you can do that here. There are currently some professional quality Mods being made with voice acting so that is always a bonus. Certainly worth $5-10 if you like Space Combat.

I remember watching Gundam and Macross Animes growing up and wishing there were video games like those. There have been many but VERY few manage to capture the scale, scope, and heart of those Mecha-Space Operas and as Space Sims died out over the past 10 years I gave up hope of seeing a great Space Opera game. Until I saw Strike Suit Zero during the Flash Sale.

Strike Suit Zero isn't a TRUE space sim in the sense but the arcade style it promotes actually meshes well with the Gundam/Macross styles. Swarms of missiles flying everywhere, ships exploding, pilots screaming out death cries as their ships fall apart around them. The action is fast and intense and after babysitting you for ONE mission, SSZ kicks it into overdrive and then into crazy what the hell how do I beat this mode. HUGE thumbs up for SSZ.

While I would love to see some version of Multiplayer emerge, the MOD tools are freely available for someone to attempt it, the single player is excellent and the story very thought out. The music sounded familiar to me as I played and as I did more research discovered it was composed by the same guy that did Homeworld. (A FANTASTIC Space Opera RTS in it's own right.)

BUY THIS GAME!
Excellent game! It's fun and challenging to play. The only problem is that the controls are a bit hard to get used to.
If you have a controller, and love a fantatic, beautiful , and a very fun space flight simluator/shooter, then this game is for you. Plus, the controls for the keyboard feels normal.

IF this was the studios first project, I am really excited to see what they do next.  For a kickstarter project, this game is really polished.  The controls feel really good once you get used to them.  I am playing with a 360 controller for PC and now I wish that all my old experiences with space sims were with this type of controller.  The dual joysticks really work well for giving you yaw.  I really like that they have different ship types and didn't focus exclusively on the Strike Suit.  Playing the Bomber or Interceptor was really enjoyable and added more variety and depth to the missions.  It was kind of nice that they control how much time you can spend in the mecha form, but I think if they would of balanced that form better, there wouldn't of been the need.  I just have a hard time with it being a sci-fi genre and them saying you need to charge the suit by shooting stuff.  Why not just have it be a thermal cool down thing or something.

The story isn't overly exciting, the main character is just a name, although they are trying to manufacture a bit of a story with him.  The story doesn't add too much depth to the game, other than serving as a minimal segway to different types of missions.  But the gameplay is really fun, and the graphics are really beautiful.  It feels really amazing when you barrel role over to the underside of a capital ship after making a turret run over the top.  It really feels like you are playing in one of the epic sci fi movie battles.  I don't think I have had a game get this right before.

If you are into the space combat sim genre, check it out.  The mech suit transformation is what this game brings to the table, along with updated controls, graphics and sound.  It makes me wish these guys had a license to redo wing commmander or tie fighter, they just need a few new writers.

A nice refresh of the space combat genre that delivers an incredibly thrilling and fast-paced combat experience.

Strike Suit Zero is indeed reminiscent of FreeSpace 2, but the addition of the ability to transform into a nimble space mech adds a whole new dimension to the experience. The game’s controls proved to be highly intuitive; it’s relatively easy to pick up, and the ships (be it fighter or mech) were an absolute joy to pilot. Once the Strike Suit is acquired, much of the challenge revolves around the careful management of flux energy, which is replenished upon successful kills, and expended when utilizing the high-powered weapons in strike mode. The story does an adequate job of tying the missions together, and even has a sufficiently interesting twist at the end. As to be expected from the genre, combat is potentially repetitive, but the game mitigates the problem by intensifying the challenge significantly as the campaign progresses, with enemy attacks becoming ever more relentless.

The game's balance does leave something to be desired however, especially with regard to its roster of ships. Once the titular Strike Suit is made available, there's little in the way of incentives to warrant the selection of other ships. Furthermore, only generic information is provided on unlocked weapons and ship upgrades (granted upon completing mission-specific challenges). Without stat-related information, most of the weapons unlocked over the course of the campaign seem pointless. i.e. It's hard to justify the choice of heavier weapons when they incur penalties (like reduced projectile velocity) without delivering a discernible difference in dps.

Graphics-wise, there's nothing revolutionary here. Nevertheless, it is a step forward as far as space combat sims are concerned. The game maintains a pleasantly minimalist (if somewhat Tron-esque) aesthetic. Each faction's vessels feature sufficiently distinctive designs with a good balance of details, and a number of missions are set against surprisingly breath-taking planetary backdrops. The bloom lighting effects can get over-the-top at times, but on the whole it fits the game well. If I were to nit-pick, some of the shortcomings would be:
- completely static HUD portraits
- inconsistent attention to detail: absurdly, some large objects like comms relays and shield generators attached to installations disappear without leaving any wreckage when destroyed

The game isn't perfect, but I personally find that it brings enough to the table to be a worthy addition to the genre. If you've been on the hunt for a new space combat simulator, this is one heck of an exhilarating ride that you wouldn't want to miss.

If you like Freespace 2 (and know what it is, for that matter) you'll like this modern day space combat sim.

Strike Suit Zero is a fantastic, if not slightly flawed, game. The environments and effects yield a strong artistic style in what many games would simply paint as a black void speckled with a few distant stars. The combat is entertaining, and the unlocks keep you replaying previous levels to improve yourself in preparation of future challenges. There is a story, and it serves its purpose to drive the game forward, but the set up for the plot isn't anything new to fans of any sci-fi. The game is reasonably challenging, which makes the all-powerful Strike mode incredibly satisfying for obliterating troublesome targets. This hyper-robot mode is limited use, however, forcing you to recharge its timer by reverting back to fighter mode. Most of the strategy of the game seems to hinge on learning where and when to transform back and forth. My biggest complaint of this game is the poor control for the mouse. Even though it offers a slider for sensitivity and deadzone separately, it always felt touchy and awkward. Thus, even though I generally find the precision of an analog stick to be lacking, I still had an easier time landing shots using my 360 controller, which it supports natively with an intelligently designed control scheme. Still, I was so pleased with Strike Suit Zero that I picked up its companion product, Strike Suit Infinity, which focuses on a score attack survival mode. I haven't enjoyed this genre this much since the days of Freespace.

A unique little Space shooter, somewhat like Rouge Squadron.  Has a nice transformation gimmick, allowing for feats of total fleet destroying badassery.  It's a tad short though, so try and catch it on sale.  Has a DLC campaign too.

This game got some unjustly bad reviews.  Its a lot of fun so far and has a nice selection of weapons and ships.  The fact you fight against and with capital ships and that scale seems done well is an added bonus.  Definitely worth it especially if you find it on sale.

The strike suit games, just so everyone knows, aren't space simulators, nor are they a Gundam-style clone. They're an arcade style space combat game, most like the Rogue Squadron games. Just don't try to play with a flight stick, it doesn't really work as good as I would have liked. PROTIP: Xbox 360 controller is the way to play this game.

Spaceships in space that are potentially Mechs.
XPLOSIONS, lasers, missiles, cruiser, carriers, lots of XPLOSIONS.
Just about the right difficulty (wish I could turn it up though for kicks).

Oh and blue - lot's of differently shaded lightblues. This game likes the colour blue.

The breathtaking space vistas aside, this is the closest I have ever felt to piloting a Gundam - taking down capital ships single-handedly and mowing down fighters. This is pretty amazing with a controller. And the music is very, very good. Seriously, even if you don't get the game, consider getting the soundtrack on iTunes or something (I got the OST as a DLC from the Steam store).

On the other hand, the difficulty curve is kind of ridiculous, even on the easiest difficulty. If you're a gamepad wizard (or an old-style masochist), I heartily recommend this game. You will have a blast. But if you, like me, just want to have casual fun blowing ♥♥♥♥ up with a Gundam, you'll be wowed by the visuals, music (awesome stuff) and general atmosphere for the first few missions then become increasingly frustrated as you hit a brick wall of insurmountable difficulty.

Caveat emptor.

An inteligent, fast, smooth, and unfailingly beautiful game.  The game is small for the sheer enjoyment it brings, and with the Mega Bundle coming wth the full soundtrack and a kick-♥♥♥ artbook, it's what I recommend to buy.  This game is an excelent sci-fi experience in a rich and well rendered universe, the characters are distinguished but not obtrusive, letting the game speak for itself, and boy does it.  Enemies are inovative when given the chance to be, and showing any weakness will result on them mercilessly pursuing you.  Not to mention the incredibly active and powerful capital ships that power through space as you dart around every nook and cranny chasing enemy fighter craft away from your ship's critical systems and opening enemy ships up for attack.\nChase and dogfight your way through swarms of enemy fighters, then switch to 'Strike Suit Mode' and completely erradicate the lot.\nI recommend this for any space combat fan, even if dogfights aren't your thing, the vistas, music, and watching massive ships slug it out around you is well worth the price.

I really enjoyed this game. Some of the main criticisms were with the control scheme and with the length of the game. Personally I got used to the controls quickly on keyboard and mouse, and if you have a controller they are supposedly better. They are also very customisable if you don't like the default system. As for the length, the game has a lot to offer for its price in my opinion, and at a reduced price you can't complain! Missions are a good length (though the checkpoint system can be rather punishing on harder missions) and it is an arcade style game in the sense that you get points for everything so replaying missions for platinum medals is encouraged.

The other main criticism was that it wasn't enough like some other space flight game that the reviewer liked. Personally I don't see how this is a valid criticism for a reviewer to make who is supposed to be reviewing this game and not one that is over ten years old. This is its own game, go watch some gameplay if you are undecided, don't presume it will be like x-wing because thats what you want it to be like, you may be dissapointed.

If you like bright flashy space combat and a game that rewards players that learn the mechanics and uses them instead of expecting it to be like that space game you played in 98 then pick it up!

13 Dec 13\nStrike Suit Zero really captured my imagination, yet cast me into nostalgia. Whether intentional or not, the fighters, the music, the engine trails, all of these point and more point to a heavy influence from the Homeworld series (a series I myself adore.) So bias this review will be based on the fact that the man behind the Music in this little gem IS the same guy responsible for the 1999 cult classic Homeworld. To gameplay: this game can be difficult to play without a gamepad as I did (last level especially as precision is required in tight hallways) but very fun to fly all the same keyboard WSAD keys to control the roll pitch and speed but using the mous to control the direction you're facing. Fun mechanic when you start getting better is using the pulling on the brakes, quickly dragging the nose of your ship in a different direction and then blasting the boost metre to shoot off in an erratic and unpredictable direction similar to tactics used in the BSG series. The graphics aren't the most up to date BUT the art style is nice nonetheless: a vivid and colourful world filled with bright Nebulae & striking backdrops which serve to make any encounter even more dramatic. Some of the levels in the story campaign allow you to use these natural effects to your Armada's tactical advantage, for example hiding a fleet in the sensor prohibiting properties of a nearbye cloud but making your presence known, drawing the enemy inside after you've rigged the path with mines and then having you and your Strike Suit Suit armed up and ready to be the last line of defence alongside 20-30 other friendly fighters. The battles taking place around you make you feel part of a larger war, taking out the individual sub-sections on a Capital Ship til it explodes leaving behind a huge derelict hull is gratifying. If I could improve on this game, I would say that it'd be nice to have a less linear mission choice; For example the ability between missions to bring up a star map and pick one of a couple of new missions would add more replayability, combined with my other suggestion to add more word play between me & my team would've served to enhance the story aspects of the game even further as it would've made me feel more empathy towards the other characters. Perhaps allowing them to reflect on the decisions that've been made during the game (ascertaining towards the mission choices or in-game decisions) and allowing for mulitple outcomes. Granted, these decisions would effectively be turning this game into an RPG which would rule in my opinion.

Overall its a great game,more of an arcade shooter but its nice and it does try to tell a story.
The controls take time to get use to but eventually are quite comfortable and you can always customize your gamepad.
The graphics are great considering this is an indie crowd funded game and so is the soundtrack.

When I bought this game originally it was $20, the marketing behind it led me to believe it would be on the same level of quality as Freespace and Homeworld but don't be fooled.\n\nIt's a pretty repetitive space shooter with a nice visual flair to it. reviewText: Trying to play this on a gamepad is just pointless as the controls there are far too sensitive, making you unable to shoot the broad side of a barn. Keyboard and mouse are a lot more easier to use and result in much improved accuracy. Visuals are fine, though nothing special. I honestly can't understand this games PC requirements being as high as they are. A complete lack of checkpoints throughout every mission I've played so far is also quite baffling and will lead to many ragequits. Weapons are pretty easy to use.\n\nAll in all, it's an....OK game at best. If you want a simple space shooter (emphasis on simple) then go for it. But in all honesty, I wouldn't recommend. There are other games out there that do it better.

If your looking for a decent dogfighting game for fun this game is exhilirating except for the last mission. I found the controls a bit clunky but aside from that the only thing that continually frustrated me was the inability for me to lock on to the specific target I wanted. The brief in game explination hardly covers the use of the system adequately and knowing where those torpedos are when the entire screen is filled with explosions is quite difficult at times. All that aside I would recommend this game but wait and get it on sale. It is not a $20.00 tittle I feel it missed out on much needed development such as character development, story depth, and scenario design. Unlike what I've seen from the rest of the reviews I had no issues with the checkpoint system incorperated they were well placed and the entire point was to make sure you werent just throwing out a million rockets willy nilly so you would have the required resources to beat the end of a mission segment and reach the begining of another checkpoint. All in all the checkpoints did not hamper me in fact they were an asset once I figured out how they were placed and I knew when it was okay to waste what I had to make it to the next checkpoint after which it was acceptable to die and get more special weapon ammo and armor.

An old school space sim with new mechanics.
Strike Suit Zero is one of the early titles developped for the Oculus Rift but if you aren't that lucky yet, don't worry this game is still great.
The universe is very immersive, with it's great open spaces and impressive color palette, the game is visually striking. But it does not end there, there is full support for any type of control method (Mouse+Keyboard, Gamepad, Joystick+Keyboard, HOTAS) and the button mapping is really intuitive (just be sure to select Joystick+Keyboard when playing with a HOTAS). However, when it comes to controlling ships, there's not much to choose from. Being a recruit you'll start with a standard fighter then shortly after you'll unlock the Strike Suit and further down some other 2 ships bringing it to a total of four ships to choose from, which is not much. But the game being named Strike Suit Zero, you already guessed what the main ship will be. It's main feature is that is can transform into a Transformer like mech and fire lock on missiles and heavy caliber both using Flux as energy, this Flux can be regenerated over time and be destroying enemy targets. So yeah, it's pretty badass. But the game does not let you be badass for long as the didfficulty of missions ramp up very quickly and the ally AI is utterly useless, forcing you to always be at your best to triumph. The old school difficulty also applies to the ranking system, if you do as you are told you might get a medal, but if you do everyones job you'll earn silver or gold. Keep in mind that there is Platinum above and since you've already won the battle to yourself there is not much left to do!

Anyway, besides its frustrating difficulty Strike Suit Zero is a fantastic experience and a worthy one if you want to prepare for StarCitizen later this year (press time). With it's challenging but rewarding gameplay, this is a game that I recommend.

Strike Suit Zero is a fantastic, if not slightly flawed, game. The environments and effects yield a strong artistic style in what many games would simply paint as a black void speckled with a few distant stars. The combat is entertaining, and the unlocks keep you replaying previous levels to improve yourself in preparation of future challenges. There is a story, and it serves its purpose to drive the game forward, but the set up for the plot isn't anything new to fans of any sci-fi. The game is reasonably challenging, which makes the all-powerful Strike mode incredibly satisfying for obliterating troublesome targets. This hyper-robot mode is limited use, however, forcing you to recharge its timer by reverting back to fighter mode. Most of the strategy of the game seems to hinge on learning where and when to transform back and forth. My biggest complaint of this game is the poor control for the mouse. Even though it offers a slider for sensitivity and deadzone separately, it always felt touchy and awkward. Thus, even though I generally find the precision of an analog stick to be lacking, I still had an easier time landing shots using my 360 controller, which it supports natively with an intelligently designed control scheme. Still, I was so pleased with Strike Suit Zero that I picked up its companion product, Strike Suit Infinity, which focuses on a score attack survival mode. I haven't enjoyed this genre this much since the days of Freespace.

reviewText: Awsome game :3

A nice refresh of the space combat genre that delivers an incredibly thrilling and fast-paced combat experience.

Strike Suit Zero is indeed reminiscent of FreeSpace 2, but the addition of the ability to transform into a nimble space mech adds a whole new dimension to the experience. The game’s controls proved to be highly intuitive; it’s relatively easy to pick up, and the ships (be it fighter or mech) were an absolute joy to pilot. Once the Strike Suit is acquired, much of the challenge revolves around the careful management of flux energy, which is replenished upon successful kills, and expended when utilizing the high-powered weapons in strike mode. The story does an adequate job of tying the missions together, and even has a sufficiently interesting twist at the end. As to be expected from the genre, combat is potentially repetitive, but the game mitigates the problem by intensifying the challenge significantly as the campaign progresses, with enemy attacks becoming ever more relentless.

The game's balance does leave something to be desired however, especially with regard to its roster of ships. Once the titular Strike Suit is made available, there's little in the way of incentives to warrant the selection of other ships. Furthermore, only generic information is provided on unlocked weapons and ship upgrades (granted upon completing mission-specific challenges). Without stat-related information, most of the weapons unlocked over the course of the campaign seem pointless. i.e. It's hard to justify the choice of heavier weapons when they incur penalties (like reduced projectile velocity) without delivering a discernible difference in dps.

Graphics-wise, there's nothing revolutionary here. Nevertheless, it is a step forward as far as space combat sims are concerned. The game maintains a pleasantly minimalist (if somewhat Tron-esque) aesthetic. Each faction's vessels feature sufficiently distinctive designs with a good balance of details, and a number of missions are set against surprisingly breath-taking planetary backdrops. The bloom lighting effects can get over-the-top at times, but on the whole it fits the game well. If I were to nit-pick, some of the shortcomings would be:
- completely static HUD portraits
- inconsistent attention to detail: absurdly, some large objects like comms relays and shield generators attached to installations disappear without leaving any wreckage when destroyed

The game isn't perfect, but I personally find that it brings enough to the table to be a worthy addition to the genre. If you've been on the hunt for a new space combat simulator, this is one heck of an exhilarating ride that you wouldn't want to miss.

Strike Suit Zero is a very unique game. It's offers a level of immersion that other space opera games lack. This is a heavy action-oriented game and the story is not merely a vehicle.  Controls are not complex and only several keys are required and the game doesn't dump a rediculous ammount on you, forcing you to stretch your hand all accross your keyboard. The plot is not pointless too. It will fool you into thinking it's a total linear story line. So SPOILER ALERT: at the very end you have a choice.

Combat is very satisfying. Ships are graceful, fair, and not clunky to handle. Controls are simple, easy to operate, and convenient. The story surprised me as stated above.

If you like mecha games such as armored core, military themed areial combat, space opera, then you will love this game and it's sequel Strike Suit Infinity.

If you're looking for a good space combat dog-fighting game then look no further. Strike Suit Zero is pretty, challenging, and fun. It also supports the Oculus Rift, if you happen to have one of those.\n\nI also highly recommend Strike Suit Infinity. Instead of following a campaign story you play a wave attack/survival mode where you can spend points to buy upgrades like allied fighters and boosts.
